Kevin Lawrence wrote:
> I try to have the method name give some indication of what /should/ 
> happen.
>
> testStackShouldContainOneElementAfterPush
> testStackShouldContainTwoElementsAfterTwoPushes
>
> The discipline of coming up with a sentence with /should/ in it helps 
> me to
> focus on what the test is really testing. I was surprised by how effective
> this turned out to be.

Sounds similar to my experience.  Glad it works for you.  I generally 
don't use "should", though.  These would be called:

testStackContainsOneElementAfterPush
testStackContainsTwoElementsAfterTwoPushes

Does "should" push you toward better tests, or is this just a stylistic 
difference?  Thanks,

    David Saff
